definitions.definition: ( intransitive , copulative ) To emit or reflect light so as to glow .
( intransitive , copulative ) To distinguish oneself; to excel .
examples: My nephew tried other sports before deciding on football, which he shone at right away, quickly becoming the star of his school team.

definitions.definition: ( intransitive , copulative ) To be effulgent in splendour or beauty .
( intransitive , copulative ) To be eminent , conspicuous , or distinguished ; to exhibit brilliant intellectual powers .
( intransitive , copulative ) To be immediately apparent .
( transitive ) To create light with (a flashlight , lamp , torch , or similar).
examples: I shone my light into the darkness to see what was making the noise.

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To cause to shine, as a light or by reflected light.
examples: in hunting, to shine the eyes of a deer at night by throwing a light on them

main_definition: ( intransitive , copulative ) To emit or reflect light so as to glow .
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive , copulative ) To distinguish oneself; to excel .
( intransitive , copulative ) To be effulgent in splendour or beauty .
( intransitive , copulative ) To be eminent , conspicuous , or distinguished ; to exhibit brilliant intellectual powers .
( intransitive , copulative ) To be immediately apparent .
( transitive ) To create light with (a flashlight , lamp , torch , or similar).
( transitive ) To cause to shine, as a light or by reflected light.

definitions.definition: To cause (something) to be smooth and shiny by rubbing; put a shine on (something); polish (something).
examples: He shined my shoes until they were polished smooth and gleaming.

definitions.definition: To polish a cricket ball using saliva and one’s clothing .

main_definition: ( transitive ) To cause (something) to be smooth and shiny by rubbing; put a shine on (something); polish (something).
secondary_definitions: ( transitive , cricket ) To polish a cricket ball using saliva and one’s clothing .
